awd_titl_txt: Conference: SMBE Satellite Meeting On De Novo Gene Birth
awd_abstract_narration:
This conference award provides partial support for The Society of Molecular Biology and Evolution Satellite Meeting on De Novo Gene Birth, to be held in College Station, TX on November 6-9, 2023. De novo gene birth is a recently discovered genetic process responsible for generating new genes with important biological roles, such as human brain function and pest resistance in crops. Research on de novo genes is critical to our understanding of species evolution and has a growing impact on medical sciences, including cancer biology. This international meeting will stimulate sharing of new knowledge and foster collaborative efforts across a variety of biological disciplines. The conference will offer outstanding networking and training opportunities for young researchers representing the future STEM workforce. 
 
De novo genes evolve from ancestrally noncoding DNA sequences and are ubiquitous across the tree of life. Research in this area encompasses a range of disciplines and has informed on broader phenomena in biological sciences, including the evolution of cellular networks, the emergence of new protein folds and domains, and the accuracy of gene annotation. The rapid increase of genome sequences and high-throughput proteomic datasets is providing the wealth of information necessary to address fundamental issues in de novo gene origin and function. As the first large scientific gathering on de novo gene birth, this conference will accelerate advances in de novo gene evolution, function, and annotation, and enable developing the conceptual and empirical frameworks that will guide investigations in this area for the foreseeable future. The meeting will provide opportunities for early-career researchers to present their work and establish a broader professional network with internationally recognized scholars in molecular evolution, genomics, proteomics, cell biology and bioinformatics. The funding provided by NSF includes support to trainees from historically underrepresented groups in science with the goal of broadening participation to the meeting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided support for the conference ‘The Society for Molecular Biology and Evolution (SMBE) satellite meeting on De Novo Gene Birth’, which was held at the Texas A&M Hotel and Conference Center in College Station, TX, on November 6-9, 2023. De novo gene birth represents a recently discovered mechanism to generate new protein-coding genes ‘from scratch’. In this process, DNA that was ancestrally noncoding accumulate mutations that enable both the formation of a long open reading frame (ORF) and the ability to be transcribed and translated. Some de novo genes are known to play a role in important phenomena, such as human brain function and pest resistance in crops. Although hundreds of de novo genes have been described across a variety of species, they remain poorly understood. A major obstacle to advancing the study of de novo gene birth is the highly interdisciplinary nature of this field, which had prevented the community of scientists working on de novo genes to gather at large society meetings. This international conference represented the first dedicated meeting to the study of de novo genes, promoting the discussion and networking among scientists from a diverse array of disciplines, including evolutionary genomics, proteomics, structural biology, molecular genetics, cell biology, and computational biology.

 

Intellectual Merit.

The meeting offered an excellent opportunity to facilitate a discussion in the growing scientific community interested on de novo genes through presentations, break-out sessions, and other gatherings. The advancement of our understanding of de novo gene evolution and function greatly benefitted from opportunities to foster extensive interactions among researchers from disciplines as different as evolutionary genomics, structural biology, molecular genetics, cell biology, and computational biology, as investigators in such a variety of fields are unlikely to converge to the same conferences. 

The conference provided an opportunity to the community to present and discuss research at the forefront of de novo genes research throughout 2 plenary lecturers, 10 talks from invited speakers, 27 contributed talks, 26 contribute posters, a round table with invited speakers and a break-out session on de novo gene birth in nonmodel organisms. A series of peer-reviewed articled will be submitted by May 2024 to the journal Genome Biology and Evolution to be published in a special section dedicated to this meeting, including an article synthesizing the main research results presented at the meeting.

 

Broader Impacts.

The meeting promoted interactions among a diverse group of researchers working on de novo genes and related fields who have had very limited chances to exchange ideas and perspectives on this topic in discipline-specific scientific conferences. The meeting also fostered excellent networking opportunities for early-career researchers in molecular evolution, genomics, genetics, proteomics, cell biology, and bioinformatics.  This event was attended by 94 participants from 41 Institutions across 11 countries and three continents (North America, Europe and Asia).  Participants included 68 trainees. Support was given to 25 trainees as travel awards, including 18 US-based trainees directly supported throughout this award. Participation of individuals from underrepresented groups in sciences was be promoted throughout extensive advertisements to professional societies for the advancements of underrepresented minorities in STEM, including The Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science, The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology and The American Indians in Science and Engineering Society. Additionally, the meeting was directly advertised to Departments of biology and related disciplines in the 61 HBCUs and HSIs in Texas. This led to scientific presentations form undergraduate and graduate students from multiple HSIs. The meeting reached out to additional audiences throughout an interview to one of the plenary speakers with graduate students of the Texas A&M Interdisciplinary Graduate Program in Genetics and Genomics who host the Blue Genes and Boots podcast.
